Award.AbstractNarration: This award is made as part of the FY 2020 Mathematical Sciences Postdoctoral Research Fellowships Program. Each of the fellowships supports a research and training project at a host institution in the mathematical sciences, including applications to other disciplines, under the mentorship of a sponsoring scientist. The title of the project for this fellowship to Pui Tung Choi is "Interplay between geometry, topology, and physics in science and engineering." The host institution for the fellowship is Massachusetts Institute of Technology, and the sponsoring scientist is Jorn Dunkel.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project focuses on the interplay between geometry, topology, and physics in science and engineering. In particular, two major directions are on (1) mathematical metamaterial design and (2) morphometrics and morphogenesis. The project outcomes are described below.

For mathematical metamaterial design, the PI has developed multiple methods for kirigami metamaterial design. Specifically, by exploring the connection between geometry and mechanics of kirigami structures, the PI has developed efficient inverse design frameworks for creating shape-shifting structures with different properties (Phys. Rev. Research 2021; Nat. Comput. Sci. 2023). Also, by considering the geometric and topological properites of wallpaper groups and quasicrystal tilings, the PI has created a wide range of novel kirigami patterns (Proc. R. Soc. A 2021; Phys. Rev. Research 2022). The PI has further developed mathematical approaches for controlling the rigidity of kirigami structures (Proc. R. Soc. A 2023) and floppy networks  (Proc. R. Soc. A 2022), thereby allowing for the design of a broader class of flexible metamaterials.

For morphometry and morphogenesis, the PI has developed several efficient and accurate geometric mapping methods for surfaces (J. Sci. Comput. 2021, 2022; IEEE RAL 2021; SIAM J. Imaging Sci. 2022; Comput. Biol. Med. 2023) and images (Inverse Prob. Imaging 2022, SIAM J. Imaging Sci. 2022), which can be applied for studying different biological shapes. The PI has also combined mapping methods with surface harmonics for analyzing a wide range of complex shapes including human brain (Signal Process. 2021, Powder Technol. 2021; Comput. Biol. Med. 2022). Besides, the PI has explored the relationship between geometry, topology and function in biology (PNAS 2021, 2023; Biol. Lett. 2023).

Altogether, the completion of this project has advanced our understanding of how a suitable combination of geometry, topology and physics can help us create novel metamaterials, and how these important factors have influenced growth and form in nature.
